title: 107_s2465
content: The text chunk states that section 290 of the Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985 is repealed, with amendments made to extend certain provisions to later years. Additionally, there is an extension of the pay-as-you-go requirement. SEC. 3 extends the pay-as-you-go requirement to October 1, 2007, with an exception for years with a surplus. SEC. 4 establishes a point of order for compliance with spending limits and pay-as-you-go. Section 312(b) of the Congressional Budget Act of 1974 is amended to include a discretionary spending limit and pay-as-you-go point of order in the Senate. It restricts the consideration of bills or resolutions that exceed discretionary spending limits or cause deficits for direct spending or revenue legislation. The text chunk discusses the conditions under which a deficit may be caused or increased according to the Budget Enforcement Act of 1990, within specific time periods outlined in budget resolutions. The Budget Enforcement Act of 1990 sets limits on discretionary spending in budget resolutions, with provisions for striking out specific sections that exceed these limits upon a sustained point of order. The Budget Enforcement Act of 1990 allows a Senator to raise a point of order under section 313(e), with provisions for handling conference reports if the point of order is sustained. Exceptions apply if there is a declaration of war or if a joint resolution under the Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985 has been enacted. SEC. 5. ENFORCEMENT AGAINST BUDGET EVASION. Amends Title III of the Congressional Budget Act of 1974 to include a "budget evasion point of order." Sec. 316 prohibits bills or resolutions that waive spending limits or alter pay-as-you-go balances set by the Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985. It also restricts directed scoring of any bill or resolution in the Senate. The section prohibits bills or resolutions from waiving spending limits or altering pay-as-you-go balances set by the Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985. It also restricts directed scoring of any bill or resolution in the Senate, with provisions for waiver and appeal by a three-fifths vote.
